title: Syllabus
text:
This is an discretionary course for master level students enrolled in the ‚ÄúBiologia Evoluzionistica, Ecologia e Antropologia Applicata‚Äù degree at the University of Rome Tor Vergata. It is worth 3 CFU for a total of 24 hours to be administered in person (or remotely, depending on the evolution of the pandemic) during the first semester of academic year 2022/2023.




Day
Time
Location




Lectures
Mon & Thu
11:00 - 13:00 & 16:00 - 18:00
Aula pesca









Note



Attendance is mandatory!

title: Syllabus
text:
Course language
The course will be thought in Italian unless international students are present. In this latter case the course will be thought in English. All the material and the literature used (including this website!) will be in English.

title: Syllabus
text:
Pre-requisites
This is an introductory course, so no prior knowledge of this topic is required. Throughout the course students will be extensively exposed to various software and web-tools. All software used is freely available and relatively easy to install. It is necessary that each student has his/her own laptop in order to better follow the various demonstrations/exercises that will take place in class. Problem-solving skills and a good knowledge of your own computer OS structure and function will definitely be useful. This course does not teach you system administration skills and you should know how to read help files and software guides, as well as retrieve information on-line. Should a student not have a portable computer, all code and demonstrations will be uploaded on this website and are available for practice on a desktop computer.






Warning



Note that most modern bioinformatic relies on Unix-based systems (macOS and Linux). That being said, the material covered in class should work fine on Windows systems as well!

title: Syllabus
text:
Textbook
As this is an introductory and discretionary course we decided not to adopt a textbook. This is not to say that there are no introductory texts available (some of them are actually really good!). For those of you with a deep interest in Bioinformatics we recommend, as starters, the following books:

Bioinformatics Data Skill
Bioinformatics for Beginners: Genes, Genomes, Molecular Evolution, Databases and Analytical Tools

title: Syllabus
text:
Additional Resources
As this course will heavily rely on the use of R we report here some very useful resources that we encourage to use.

StackOverflow
Bioconductor
Modern Statistics for Modern Biology
Un Viaggio nell‚ÄôAmbiente R

title: Syllabus
Syllabus
text:
Class evaluation
The assessment of the students‚Äô learning level will take place throughout the course,
Students‚Äô evaluation is based on three main aspects:

Participation to class and discussions;
Paper presentation;
Project.


Participation to class and discussion
Through the discussion of primary literature on the main subject. The critical comparison of the various methodologies of data acquisition, organization and processing will constitute the basis for the formulation of the student‚Äôs final judgment. Aspects that will be used to assess students‚Äô learning level are their participation and interaction during the course and their ability to present and discuss scientific literature articles.


Paper presentation
Each student will, taking turns, be assigned a paper that he/she will present at the beginning of the next class. The presentation should consist of a PowerPoint (or .pdf or .slides) no longer than 20 minutes (~15 slides). At the end of each presentation the audience will have 10 minutes to ask questions or discuss the material presented. Each student in the audience has to prepare at least one question to ask the presenter.






Important



Even if you are not presenting the paper you still have to read it carefully to prepare your question and actively participate in the discussion!!




Project
Towards the end of class each student will be assigned a data set. To pass the course with full marks, the student should submit a report related to a project that he/sge would have developed starting from the assigned data set. Each student will have to use all the skills acquired during class, analyse the data set and submit the final project for evaluation. All the instructions on how to format the final report will be illustrated in class and added on this website.


Grading



Category
Percentage




Participation
15%


Paper Presentation
35%


Project
50%

title: Syllabus
text:
Students with disabilities
Please let us know if you require special accommodations to follow this class.

title: Class 2
text:
What‚Äôs a study design?



Note


Set of methods and procedures used to collect and analyze data on variables specified in a particular research problem









Important


It is always important to undersand WHAT we want to do before start doing it!

title: Class 2
text:
What is metabarcoding?



Note


From Wikipedia Metabarcoding is the barcoding of DNA/RNA (or eDNA/eRNA) in a manner that allows for the simultaneous identification of many taxa within the same sample.




Metabarcoding

title: Class 2
Class 2
text:
Target sequence
the sequence within the DNA template, which will be amplified by PCR

title: Class 2
text:
PCR primers
single-stranded DNA (usually 18‚Äì25 nucleotides long), which match the sequences at the ends of or within the target DNA, and these are required to start DNA synthesis in PCR.

Note


Worry not, the quiz result will not count towards your final grade!

title: Class 1
text:
What is Bioinformatics?



From Wikipedia


Bioinformatics is an interdisciplinary field that develops methods and software tools for understanding biological data, in particular when the data sets are large and complex. [‚Ä¶] bioinformatics combines biology, chemistry, physics, computer science, information engineering, mathematics and statistics [‚Ä¶] using computational and statistical techniques.







Important


Bioinformaticians deal with a variety of different type of data! We are not bioinformaticians!! We are evolutionary biologists!! We will focus on nucleotide sequence data trying not to lose focus of the research questions we are interested in.

title: Class 1
text:
Why Bioinformatics


Back in the days, biologists could analyze their data on personal computers. Sanger Sequecing produced anywhere between 50 and 1000 nucleotides at a time. It took time and resources to combine many sequences.
Since 1994 scientist have begun developing new technologies to parallelize DNA sequencing and produce high throughput data.
As these technologies improve, biologists need to harness the tools to design meaningful experiments, produce the data, and analyse them.

title: Class 1
text:
To visualize and analyse data and to produce reports we will be using R and RStudio. These are free cross-platform software.

Visit the R page and download the version compatible to your OS. Install the software following the instructions.
Visit the RStudio page and download the desktop version compatible with your OS. Install the software following the instructions.

title: Class 1
text:
Warning


Learning all the specifics of R and RStudio is beyond the scope of this course. We will be doing a brief introduction to these tools, but it is a student‚Äôs responsibility to learn how to use them in an efficient way.









Tip


Remember that both teachers are available to help you figuring things out!

title: Class 1
Class 1
text: R-Studio screenshot. You can change many of the aspects parameters (colors, font, panes etc.etc‚Ä¶).

title: Class 1
Class 1
text:
Packages
There are thousands of available libraries (aka, packages) that can be used to perform very specific analyses and produce publication-grade graphical output.

sI <- sessionInfo()
sI$basePkgs

[7] "base"

title: Schedule
text:
Read carefully!



It is a student‚Äôs responsibility to periodically check this website to make sure he/she has the most updated information about the course schedule.

title: ABEM 22-23
text:
Read carefully!



It is a student‚Äôs responsibility to periodically check this website to make sure he/she has the most updated information about the course and classes.


The course aims to train students in basic bioinformatics techniques for the analysis of molecular ecology data (genetic and genomic data). The course offers an overview of the tools for the production, organization, and analysis of molecular data aimed at ecological investigations.

(Image downloaded from this webpage)






Acknowledgement



Inspiration to build this website using R-Studio and Quarto comes from the class course developed by Dr.¬†Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel available here. The main structure of this website is inspired by her work, and the freely available code has been tweaked, rearranged, and posted on GitHub.

text: Drop of sequencing cost for Genomes and Nucleotides. Data from https://www.genome.gov/about-genomics/fact-sheets/DNA-Sequencing-Costs-Data

title: Class 1
text:
A single nucleotide takes approximately 1 byte (i.e., 8-bit) of memory (this is may vary based on the type of encoding used by the system, but it is a good approximation).

Binary code scheme for nucleotides as implemented in the ape package (Paradis, 2012)

title: Class 1
text: Bit-level coding scheme as implemented in the ape package (Paradis, 2012)

title: Class 1
text:
To visualize and analyse data and to produce reports on all the activities of this course we will be using R and RStudio. These are free cross-platform software.

Visit the R (https://cran.r-project.org) page and download the R version compatible to your OS. Install the software following the instructions.
Visit the RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/) page and download the RStudio Desktop version compatible with your OS. Install the software following the instructions.

title: Class 1
text: NOTE: RStudio is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) within which it should be easier to organize your R workflow. Learning all the specifics of R and RStudio is beyond the scope of this course and it is a student‚Äôs responsibility to learn the basics of these tools. That being said, you can always write me with your questions if something does not work on your computer and I will help troubleshooting potential issues.

OK, but how big?

title: Class 1
text: R-Studio screenshot. You can change many of the aspects parameters (colors, font, panes etc.etc‚Ä¶).

title: Class 1
text:
A little math‚Ä¶
Genome sizes are given in either unit of mass (picograms, \(1pg = 10^{-12}g\)) or in number of base pairs (megabases, \(1Mb = 10^6bases\)).

title: Class 1
text:
A small example

start_codon <- "atg"

bp_1000 <- paste(sample(c("a", "c", "t", "g"), 1000, 
                      replace = T),
               collapse = "")
start.time <- Sys.time()
bp_1000 <- gsub(start_codon, "ATG", bp_1000)
end.time <- Sys.time()
time.taken <- end.time - start.time
time.taken

Time difference of 0.0005619526 secs




bp_1e6 <- paste(sample(c("a", "c", "t", "g"), 1e6, 
                        replace = T),
                 collapse = "")
start.time <- Sys.time()
bp_1e6 <- gsub(start_codon, "ATG", bp_1e6)
end.time <- Sys.time()
time.taken <- end.time - start.time
time.taken

Time difference of 0.01762009 secs

title: Class 1
text:
A number cruncher on steroids

# basic arithmetic
3 + 5

[1] 8




# assigning values to object
a <- 5
b <- 3
(c <- a + b)

[1] 8
